U.S. mad cow case was Texas-born   
 Last Updated Wed, 29 Jun 2005 21:09:40 EDT 
 CBC News </news/credit.html< 
 American officials say the second case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease, in the U.S. was a cow born, raised and slaughtered in Texas. 
 
 The U.S. Department of Agriculture confirmed the diagnosis on Friday but had to wait for DNA analysis to confirm the cow's origin. 
 
 The USDA says the cow was killed at a pet food plant after it was determined to be unfit for human consumption. 
 "The testing and traceback efforts may yield further information as to how this animal became infected," said USDA chief veterinarian John Clifford in a statement on the department's website. 
 
 "The safety of our food supply is not in question ... American beef is among the safest in the world." 
 
 Officials say the 12-year-old cow couldn't stand on its own feet. 
 At its age, the cow could have have contracted the disease before a regulation was introduced banning feed that included animal parts. 
 
 The U.S. banned using cattle parts in such feed after 1997 following an outbreak of mad cow disease in Britain. 
 
 The U.S. closed its borders to Canadian beef more than two years ago after BSE was confirmed in one cow in northern Alberta. Plans to reopen the border to live imports of Canadian cattle under 30 months were stymied by court injunctions from U.S. cattle lobbyists.

 BSE is not a mutation, nor is it even a disease in the traditional sense of being caused by a virus or bacteria. It's caused by a mis-folded protein, a prion. You can either injest it, or it will happen spontaneously on rare occasions. 
 
 I'm not saying that vegetarian species eating meat won't run into problems caused by that behavior, but BSE isn't one of them. BSE isn't caused by the cow's vegetarian system being unable to deal with meat. If you could somehow get a plant that had the prion in question and fed it to the cows they would still get BSE. It's the prion that causes the symptoms, not the cow's being unable to handle meat. Humans are omnivorous, we can handle meat just fine, and yet if we eat infected humans than we catch the human equivalent of BSE.
